Next to the slasher films of the 1970s and 80s, ones about the walking dead were probably the second most popular horror sub-genre in modern times. The success of George A. Romero’s 1968 Night of the Living Dead spawned the full-feature zombie craze in the decades to follow. Not that popular since the ‘80s and ‘90s, these films have helped the horror genre’s evolution since the time these films have been created

Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US — a land where anyone from anywhere can pick themselves up, put down roots, start anew, thrive, succeed—in other words, a land of immigrants and opportunity. And one where the taxpayers pay for everything.

The Dutch — a place that values privileged educations, subsidizes foreign workers, and pays

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to 19th Century filmmaking.
The story of a young photographer attempting to capture the life of his people - the Maori - is a genuinely touching outcome.
This film would make an excellent History Film Club choice and is very educational.
Evan Rutherford
